subject: RE: [junit] assert failure without exiting test.
msgSnippet: I don t understand why you had to do this. I didn t try it, but I think my solution already would print a readable error message for every failing test.
messageBody:
I don't understand why you had to do this. I didn't try it, but I think
my solution already would print a readable error message for every
failing test.

Bryan LaPlante wrote:
> What I have had to do in this case is set up an ArrayList for
> tracking the failures and the last test to run checks the
> size of the ArrayList for any failures that were added and
> then populate a fail with a delimited string that makes a
> somewhat readable fail message.
>
> ArrayList failures = null;
>
> public void setUp throws Exception{
> failures = new ArrayList();
> }
>
> public void testLast(){
> if(failures.size() > 0){
> StringBuffer messageString = new StringBuffer();
> for(int i=0; i > failures.size(); i++){
> messageString.append("[ " + failures.get(i) + " ] : ")
> } fail(messageString.toString());
> }
> }
>
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: "Ilja Preuss" <preuss@...>
> To: <junit@yahoogroups.com>
> Sent: Monday, March 29, 2004 8:26 AM
> Subject: RE: [junit] assert failure without exiting test.
>
>
>> javayang@... wrote:
>>> Howdy folks,
>>>
>>> I have a test method that iteratres through a String array
>>> performing assert checks. The problem I have is on the first
>>> failure, the tests discontinues and the rest of the array is not
>>> checked. This makes sense because of the exception that is thrown
>>> and handled by JUNIT. Is there a away I can keep the loop running
>>> until it finishes all the strings. I can catch the exception but
>>> how do I add it to the current aggregate test results that JUNIT is
>>> keeping track of. Also, is this the best way or proper way to do
>>> this? I don't think it makes very much sense to write a test method
>>> for each string in the arry, it wouldn't be very scalable or
>>> dynamic. Thanks in advance for any help or advice.
>>
>> I think you could write a test *suite* for this. Perhaps something
>> along the lines of
>>
>> public class FooTest extends TestCase {
>>
>> public FooTest(int testValue) {
>> this.testValue = testValue;
>> }
>>
>> public void testBar() {
>> assertEquals(..., myFoo.bar(testValue));
>> }
>>
>> public static Test suite() {
>> TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();
>> for ...
>> suite.addTest(new FooTest(i));
>> }
>> return suite;
>> }
>> }
>>
>> ???
>>
>> Take care, Ilja
